title: Welcome to the Active Attack Data Explorer
section: History of the Active Attack Project
text:
History of the Active Attack Project
ALERRT started collecting data from active shooter events in 2010 in an effort to better understand how the attacks unfold and to inform ALERRT’s curriculum. This original dataset was focused on events where the attacker used a firearm. Around 2018, we expanded the definition to include attacks where any weapon was used in an attempt to commit mass murder. We started referring to this expanded data as the Active Attack data.
ALERRT’s research ring partnered with the FBI to form an Active Shooter Working Group in 2013. Since then, we have assisted with the FBI’s annual reporting of active shooter events. The Active Attack Dataset includes all the FBI firearm attacks plus additional non-firearm attacks found by ALERRT’s research team.

title: Welcome to the Active Attack Data Explorer
text:
Definitions
The definition we use to vet potential active attacks is the following: an active attack occurs when an individual or individuals is actively killing or attempting to kill multiple unrelated people in a public space. The key component of the definition is the word “actively”. For an event to be an active attack there must be an active component. This requirement removes cases where law enforcement is not aware the attack is happening. A good example of this is a family annihilation. In many of these events, the attacker kills his/her family in their private home. Law enforcement is not made aware of the attack until well after it is over and is unable to intervene to save lives. During an active attack, first responders generally are made aware of the attack while it is still ongoing. As you will see in the data, half of the time the event is over before law enforcement makes it to the scene because the attacker is stopped by civilians or stops himself (e.g., flees the scene or commits suicide).
Another important feature is that active attacks are not limited to attacks carried out with a firearm. Instead, active attacks include events where a firearm, knife, or even vehicle is used as the primary weapon. Any weapon can be used in an active attack as long as the primary concern is an attempt to kill as many people as possible.

title: Welcome to the Active Attack Data Explorer
text:
Website Guide
There are several different pages on this website that may be of interest.

Active Attacks
The Active Attacks page presents many visualizations created by our team to show different aspects of the data. All visualization are downloadable as .png/.gif/.mp4 files. There are several sub-pages that organize these visualizations:

By The Numbers: Counts and percentages of event characteristics (e.g., date/time, location type/ relationship), shooter characteristics (e.g., race/ethnicity, number of shooters, number of weapons), and fatalities.
Across The USA: Geographic distribution of attacks across the USA. This page includes plots as well as maps.
Download The Data: This page allows users to view the data underlying all of the visualizations. In addition to viewing the data, users can download the data directly as a .csv file.



Remembrance
The Remembrance page catalogs all victims who died because of the attacks included in the Active Attack dataset.


Contact
The Contact page provides contact information for the members of the Research Ring at the ALERRT Center.

title: Active Attack Data Explorer
text:
Between 2000 and 2023, our nation has experienced 568 active attack events. There were a total of 3,917 people injured, and out of that number, 1,383 people died. This page attempts to list every name of every victim. Please alert us if any mistakes or omissions are found. We attempt to capture every name we can find to remember the victims.
Let us pause for a moment of silence to remember and honor those lost. ALERRT also strives to honor with courage and compassion the thousands of surviving families and those who risked their lives to save others.

title: Active Attack Data Explorer
text:
Don’t Name Them
At ALERRT, it is our policy to refrain from naming the person or people responsible for active attacks. Research has shown that many attacks are the result of fame-seeking behavior by the shooters. By refusing to name them, we aim to remove fame and notoriety as possible motivators of future attacks. Below are listed several resources and research papers examining the effect of naming and the movement to deprive would-be shooters of any additional motivation.
